message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and imaging findings suggest the possibility of mesothelioma, a cancer often associated with exposure to asbestos. Among the options, only calretinin-positive polygonal cells with numerous long surface microvilli are characteristic of mesothelioma. Synaptophysin-positive cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scarce cytoplasm are characteristic of neuroendocrine tumors, while Napsin-positive cells with intracytoplasmatic mucin are characteristic of lung adenocarcinoma. Keratin-producing cells with intercellular bridges are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest lung cancer and the pleural thickening with calcifications indicates mesothelioma. Option B describes the pathologic findings of mesothelioma, which is positive for calretinin and has long surface microvilli. The other options refer to different types of lung cancer with different pathologic findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history and CT scan findings suggest malignant mesothelioma, in which case the biopsy specimen is most likely to show calretinin-positive polygonal cells with numerous long surface microvilli. Option A describes neuroendocrine tumors, Option C describes lung adenocarcinoma, and Option D describes squamous cell carcinoma, all of which are less likely to be associated with the patient’s symptoms and CT scan findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and the imaging findings suggest mesothelioma, which is associated with asbestos exposure from his occupation. Pathologic examination of a biopsy specimen of the thickened tissue is most likely to show Calretinin-positive polygonal cells with numerous long surface microvilli. Synaptophysin-positive dark blue cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scarce cytoplasm are characteristic of small cell lung carcinoma. Napsin-positive cells in an acinar growth pattern with intracytoplasmatic mucin are characteristic of adenocarcinoma of the lung. Keratin-producing large polygonal cells with intercellular bridges are characteristic of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a possible lung cancer with pleural involvement, and the CT scan shows pleural effusion and thickening with calcifications. Calretinin is a marker for mesothelioma, a type of cancer commonly associated with asbestos exposure, which can present with similar symptoms and radiographic findings. The other options are more commonly associated with different types of lung cancer (small cell, adenocarcinoma, and squamous cell, respectively).

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history and imaging suggest mesothelioma, a type of cancer associated with exposure to asbestos. Among the options, only option (B) describes cells that are positive for the Calretinin marker, which is commonly used to differentiate mesothelioma from lung adenocarcinoma. The long surface microvilli seen in these cells are characteristic of mesothelioma cells. Option (A) describes cells found in neuroendocrine tumors, (C) describes cells found in lung adenocarcinoma, and (D) describes cells found in squamous cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and CT scan findings suggest mesothelioma, which is associated with exposure to asbestos. Calretinin is a biomarker for mesothelioma and is positive in polygonal cells with numerous long surface microvilli. The other options are not associated with mesothelioma. Synaptophysin is a biomarker for neuroendocrine tumors, Napsin for adenocarcinoma, and Keratin for squamous cell carcinoma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Left-sided pleural effusion and circumferential pleural thickening with calcifications on the left hemithorax suggest the most likely diagnosis to be mesothelioma, which is associated with exposure to asbestos. Calretinin is a marker for mesothelioma cells, and the polygonal shape with numerous long surface microvilli is a characteristic feature of these cells. Synaptophysin is a marker for neuroendocrine tumors, Napsin is a marker for lung adenocarcinoma, and keratin is a marker for various forms of carcinoma, but they are not specific to mesothelioma.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The CT scan shows pleural effusion and thickening with calcifications, suggestive of mesothelioma, a type of cancer associated with asbestos exposure. The biopsy specimen findings will most likely show Calretinin-positive polygonal cells with numerous long surface microvilli, which are characteristic of mesothelioma. The other options represent different types of cancer: (A) small cell lung cancer, (C) adenocarcinoma of the lung, and (D) squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The clinical presentation suggests mesothelioma, a type of cancer associated with asbestos exposure. Option B describes the immunohistochemical findings of epithelioid mesothelioma, which is the most common subtype. Synaptophysin and napsin are markers for neuroendocrine and lung adenocarcinomas respectively, and keratin-producing cells are found in many types of cancer.
